entry.value: This page covers the different types of validation available in Rapid.

On the last page we covered validation on a variety of different controls. Here we are going to explore the different types of validation and provide examples for each of them. Certain types of these validations are specifically catered to certain controls, such as the different date formats. We will be going into detail about these below.

As a reference point, this example will be using the any value validation. The input boxes below will be validated against the 'Validate' button. As long as there is data in the input boxes we will pass this validation.

With any value validation covered we can now move on to the different types of validation that we have not gone into detail over. The next example will be on numbers and integers. Whilst similar in their function, they perform slightly different from one another. The number validation is used for numbers that could be decimal or negative. The integer validation is for whole numbers specifically.

validation.message: Please enter a whole, negative, or decimal number

entry.value: Moving on from numbers, we are going to cover the different date formats. These can work with input boxes, but they are specifically developed with the date control in mind. The date control and the date validation types must match up when selecting the date or entering a date manually. Any other types of format will fail validation. Rapid provides a fair amount of date options to choose, ranging from British formatting, American formatting and database formatting. For these dates we will be allowing manual data entry.

validation.message: Please enter a date in the British format (dd/mm/yyyy)
Please enter a date in the American format (mm/dd/yyyy)
Please enter a date in reverse British format (yyyy-mm-dd)
Please enter a date in SQL format (dd-MMM-yyyy)

entry.value: Following date validation comes currency and emails. Whilst it may seem a little unrelated to join the two together in an example the next two examples require their own space, as you will see shortly. Email validation is as you would expect, requiring the standard format to include an @ and ending in a .com or .co.uk address. Currency is handled like normal numbers, except it expects a decimal point after the leading numbers. Currency symbols are not supported in inputs and the decimal place is mandatory.

validation.message: Please enter a valid email address

entry.value: At this point it is worth mentioning that we have reached the end on all the simple validations. The next forms of validation are custom and javascript, meaning they are for more advanced users of Rapid. They are catered towards more advanced users due to being completely customisable. These two validation types are open ended, and you can create some really advanced, complicated validation rules. Below are just a few, simple examples of these validation types.

validation.message: Please enter a currency in or $, with or without a decimal
Please enter a valid email address

entry.value:
[{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P9_C34_","text":"There are different event triggers for validation, however we will only be focusing on the change event for these examples. For more information regarding this please click on this hint to go to a video on our Youtube channel that goes into more detail about when to use the different events and for what situation.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P9_C74_","text":"The number validation is a more open type of validation, and is a lot more lenient with the number types entered. For general purposes the number validation is used more than the integer, due to being easier to understand. For more restricted use it can be ideal to use the integer, in events where you only want users to enter whole numbers.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P9_C76_","text":"When choosing a format it is important to bear in mind the type of audience that is entering the date, based on their location or where the date is going. With the date control it is possible to make the control only have a date entered through the control itself, and not have any manual entry. In some cases, to avoid human typing errors and to ensure formatting, this is what we want to go for. In other cases it does not matter what a user enters.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P9_C111_","text":"It is worth remembering that the other formats for the date control are displayed in words, meaning they count as such. As this is the case, they fall under the 'any value' validation type as opposed to dedicated date validation. As this is the case we are not including them in this current example.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P9_C172_","text":"The custom validation is coded using RegEx, and the javascript validation is, of course, coded in javascript. There are no limits to these two, which
is what makes them such advanced validation types, worthy of their own separate section. The only limiting factor worth considering is that you will
need to find the specific controls you are targeting when using javascript. This is also hinted at when making a new javascript validation.
This can be done easily in Rapid Admin, by ticking the box to show control IDs.","type":"hover"}]

For more information regarding this please click on this hint to go to a video on our Youtube channel that goes into more detail about when to use the different events and for what situation.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P9_C74_","text":"The number validation is a more open type of validation, and is a lot more lenient with the number types entered. For general purposes the number validation is used more than the integer, due to being easier to understand. For more restricted use it can be ideal to use the integer, in events where you only want users to enter whole numbers.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P9_C76_","text":"When choosing a format it is important to bear in mind the type of audience that is entering the date, based on their location or where the date is going. With the date control it is possible to make the control only have a date entered through the control itself, and not have any manual entry. In some cases, to avoid human typing errors and to ensure formatting, this is what we want to go for. In other cases it does not matter what a user enters.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P9_C111_","text":"It is worth remembering that the other formats for the date control are displayed in words, meaning they count as such. As this is the case, they fall under the 'any value' validation type as opposed to dedicated date validation. As this is the case we are not including them in this current example.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P9_C172_","text":"The custom validation is coded using RegEx, and the javascript validation is, of course, coded in javascript. There are no limits to these two, which
is what makes them such advanced validation types, worthy of their own separate section. The only limiting factor worth considering is that you will
need to find the specific controls you are targeting when using javascript. This is also hinted at when making a new javascript validation.
This can be done easily in Rapid Admin, by ticking the box to show control IDs.","type":"hover"}]}

page.htmlBody:
This page covers the different types of validation available in Rapid.

On the last page we covered validation on a variety of different controls. Here we are going to explore the different types of validation and provide examples for each of them. Certain types of these validations are specifically catered to certain controls, such as the different date formats. We will be going into detail about these below.
As a reference point, this example will be using the any value validation. The input boxes below will be validated against the 'Validate' button. As long as there is data in the input boxes we will pass this validation.
First name
Last name
With any value validation covered we can now move on to the different types of validation that we have not gone into detail over. The next example will be on numbers and integers. Whilst similar in their function, they perform slightly different from one another. The number validation is used for numbers that could be decimal or negative. The integer validation is for whole numbers specifically.
Temp
Current age
Moving on from numbers, we are going to cover the different date formats. These can work with input boxes, but they are specifically developed with the date control in mind. The date control and the date validation types must match up when selecting the date or entering a date manually. Any other types of format will fail validation. Rapid provides a fair amount of date options to choose, ranging from British formatting, American formatting and database formatting. For these dates we will be allowing manual data entry.
British date of birth
American date of birth
Year first date of birth
SQL format date of birth
Following date validation comes currency and emails. Whilst it may seem a little unrelated to join the two together in an example the next two examples require their own space, as you will see shortly. Email validation is as you would expect, requiring the standard format to include an @ and ending in a .com or .co.uk address. Currency is handled like normal numbers, except it expects a decimal point after the leading numbers. Currency symbols are not supported in inputs and the decimal place is mandatory.
Shopping costs
Email address
At this point it is worth mentioning that we have reached the end on all the simple validations. The next forms of validation are custom and javascript, meaning they are for more advanced users of Rapid. They are catered towards more advanced users due to being completely customisable. These two validation types are open ended, and you can create some really advanced, complicated validation rules. Below are just a few, simple examples of these validation types.
Current earnings
Email address
page.name: 11_validation

rolesHtml.html:
This page covers the different types of validation available in Rapid.

On the last page we covered validation on a variety of different controls. Here we are going to explore the different types of validation and provide examples for each of them. Certain types of these validations are specifically catered to certain controls, such as the different date formats. We will be going into detail about these below.
As a reference point, this example will be using the any value validation. The input boxes below will be validated against the 'Validate' button. As long as there is data in the input boxes we will pass this validation.
First name
Last name
With any value validation covered we can now move on to the different types of validation that we have not gone into detail over. The next example will be on numbers and integers. Whilst similar in their function, they perform slightly different from one another. The number validation is used for numbers that could be decimal or negative. The integer validation is for whole numbers specifically.
Temp
Current age
Moving on from numbers, we are going to cover the different date formats. These can work with input boxes, but they are specifically developed with the date control in mind. The date control and the date validation types must match up when selecting the date or entering a date manually. Any other types of format will fail validation. Rapid provides a fair amount of date options to choose, ranging from British formatting, American formatting and database formatting. For these dates we will be allowing manual data entry.
British date of birth
American date of birth
Year first date of birth
SQL format date of birth
Following date validation comes currency and emails. Whilst it may seem a little unrelated to join the two together in an example the next two examples require their own space, as you will see shortly. Email validation is as you would expect, requiring the standard format to include an @ and ending in a .com or .co.uk address. Currency is handled like normal numbers, except it expects a decimal point after the leading numbers. Currency symbols are not supported in inputs and the decimal place is mandatory.
Shopping costs
Email address
At this point it is worth mentioning that we have reached the end on all the simple validations. The next forms of validation are custom and javascript, meaning they are for more advanced users of Rapid. They are catered towards more advanced users due to being completely customisable. These two validation types are open ended, and you can create some really advanced, complicated validation rules. Below are just a few, simple examples of these validation types.
Current earnings
Email address

page.title: Validation types
